awd_titl_txt: Enhancing Community Resilience to Floods: A Theoretical Framework of Community Participation in Federal Voluntary Programs
awd_abstract_narration:
There has been a growing interest in using voluntary programs as a salient policy tool for mitigating the effects of various hazards, including those associated with flooding. Yet many federal voluntary programs are finding it hard to increase rates of participation and/or compliance. More broadly, there is no explicit and comprehensive theoretical framework to explain the reasons for such low rates among communities. Accordingly, this work will develop a novel theoretical framework of community participation in federal voluntary programs for the mitigation of flood-related risk by integrating key insights from multiple disciplines such as political science, public administration, environmental economics, nonprofit management and sociology. This research will support policy making in the design and implementation of targeted policies to encourage communities to participate in federal voluntary programs, and improve compliance in areas such as community resilience to floods, environmental protection and adaptation, and critical infrastructure protection.

The scientific objective this work pursues is the development of a theory of participation in voluntary programs for flood risk mitigation, resulting in improved understanding of the factors that motivate communities to participate in federal voluntary programs in general. This study will address this objective in the context of the Community Rating System (CRS) through two guiding research questions: (1) What factors motivate communities to participate in the CRS program? (2) What are the differences between CRS participating communities and non-CRS participating communities with regard to flood risk management practices and contextual factors?  The CRS, a Federal voluntary program designed to promote local flood resilience, is an appropriate testbed because only 5 percent of the over 22,000 eligible communities are participating in the CRS. Primary and secondary data sources will be used, including archival and interview data. Prior to conducting the interviews, the study will use Propensity Score Matching techniques to match 50 randomly selected CRS participating communities (treatment group) with 50 non-CRS participating communities (control group). The matching will be based on community-level characteristics such as population size, median housing values, and flood risk. The study's findings are expected to advance scientific understanding of the drivers of community participation in a host of federal voluntary programs.

Dr. Abdul-Akeem Sadiq (Principal Investigator (PI)) & Dr. Douglas (Co-PI) Noonan received $201,722 grant from the National Science Foundation (September 1, 2016 ? August 31, 2018). Both researchers were at Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis at the School of Public and Environmental Affairs (now known as Paul H. O'Neill School of Public and Environmental Affairs). In 2017, Dr. Sadiq left for the School of Public Administration at the University of Central Florida (UCF).

 

The overall goal of this project is to understand the factors that motivate communities to participate in federal voluntary programs. This study examines this question in the context of the Community Rating System (CRS), and tests propositions using a dataset consisting of seven different secondary data sources and primary interview data. The CRS is a voluntary program, created in 1990 by Congress to incentivize communities to implement floodplain management activities beyond the minimum required under the NFIP. Homeowners in NFIP participating communities can purchase flood insurance, and in exchange, their state and local governments will enact and enforce floodplain management ordinances. To compensate communities for adopting additional flood risk management measures, communities enjoy reductions in their flood insurance premiums.

 

The investigators developed a questionnaire and the Institute for Social and Behavioral Science at UCF conducted the interviews via phone. Specifically, 100 floodplain managers and 100 CRS coordinators were interviewed. The interviews began in the Fall of 2018 and concluded in August of 2019. Before conducting the interviews, the investigators used Propensity Score Matching techniques to match 100 randomly selected CRS participating communities (treatment group) with 100 non-CRS participating communities (control group). The matching was based on community-level characteristics, such as population size, median housing values, and flood risk. The CRS is an appropriate testbed because only 5 percent of the over 22, 000 eligible communities are participating in the CRS. The goal of the interview was to answer  the following two questions. (1) What factors motivate communities to participate in the CRS program? (2) What are the differences between CRS participating communities and non-CRS participating communities with regard to flood risk management practices and contextual factors?

 

Some Significant Results from the Project

  1. Significant factors that predict why communities participate in the CRS program include, financial resources, flood risk factors (e.g., percent of community area covered by water), socio-economic characteristics (e.g., racial composition), and political economy factors (e.g., housing values and household income).
  2. Factors predicting a community?s participation in the CRS differ from factors predicting the number of CRS points that a community receives.
  3. Communities respond strategically to CRS incentives. Characteristics of those communities behaving strategically depends on the size of the CRS incentives.
  4. There are unintended consequences associated with the CRS vis-?-vis poverty, income inequality, migration, and development.
    1. The CRS program attracts poor residents, but relocates them away from floodplains.
    2. The CRS program encourages income inequality, but discouraging income inequality in areas that are highly susceptible to flooding.
    3. The CRS program discourages new construction and the construction of mobile homes or trailers in participating communities.
    4. The CRS program discourages population growth, but encourages people to stay in CRS participating communities.
    5. The number one reason why communities participate in the community rating system program according to CRS coordinators is the reduction in flood insurance premiums.
    6. The number one reason why communities do not participate in the community rating system according to floodplain managers is due to a lack of resources, such as funding, time, and staff.

 

Supplemental Funding

 

In 2019, the PI applied for and received the Non-Academic Research Internships for Graduate Students (INTERN) Supplemental Funding Opportunity?$42,544. This supplemental grant was used to fund the graduate student working on this NSF grant, Jenna Tyler (now Dr. Jenna Tyler), to complete an internship with the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) from September 2019 through December 2019. Jenna received a letter of commendation from FEMA after the internship was completed.

 

Workshop on Community Flood Risk Management

The investigators organized a half-day workshop on Community Flood Risk Management that took place on February 28, 2019, at the University of Central Florida. The workshop brought 29 practitioners, students, and scholars together to discuss the challenges associated with mitigating flood hazards, current developments in the field of community flood risk management, and ideas on how to improve communities? resilience to future flood disasters. Funds from the grant was used to enrich the academic and professional development of an underrepresented student from the Bill Anderson Fund (BAF). The BAF student council member, Dont? Council was given a travel stipend to attend the workshop in person. Other participants at the workshop included practitioners, academics from engineering and other disciplines, and UCF students.

 

The investigators published 12 refereed articles, and gave presentations at international (3), national (9), and local (6) conferences. They also gave invited speeches/presentations (3).
